comment: A quiz is given every day and there are mandatory sessions outside of class. He was very hard to understand, and the material was not well understood.

Prof. Hershkovits is a very nice person but he spends way too much time on formulas rather than the relationship between things; However, he IS a very easy grader if you do your part and put in the effort; he's definitely willing to meet you halfway.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: I had Professor Hershkovits for PHYS 1111L, and he is a really good lab professor. His accent is very hard to understand, but he wants to help you. As long as you ask questions, you will do good in lab! I have gotten an A on each report just from asking questions and making sure he is okay with my answers! You can also drop your lowest lab.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Youre waisting your time! 80% of my class failed. He teaches AP physics on the low (which he said to the class) he gives too much hw and he is very bad with explaining. He goes too fast. You ask him to slow down he continues to go fast. If you are confused and ask a question, he wont give u a clear explanation youll still end up confused.

did not feel like into course, very smart man but not the best teacher. goes very fast even when he claims to be taking it slow. He has a very thick accent not too bad to understand, but does not pair well with terrible handwriting. If you plan to take a full load, this prob isn't the class for you. 75% weighted in tests. lots of hw weighed little
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Prof. Hershkovits is a very good professor.  The reason I say this is because he does care if you learn the material and he does put forth the effort to help you understand.  The break-out sessions are mandatory but you will learn a great deal.  Just remember to learn the concepts of the material because this is what he is really looking for.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: He wants you to pass the class and he can tell when you put work in. DO THE HOMEWORK AND GO TO THE BREAKOUT SESSIONS. He's most helpful during the breakout sessions and wishes there were more of those than lectures!! The homework is how you'll really learn the material- both ungraded and graded.
Dr. Hershkovits is really not that bad. If you do the homework and understand what's going on, the class isn't terribly difficult. He's a very nice guy and will help if you go to his office hours.

Eliezar is a great guy. He is foreign so that means it can be hard to understand him both vocally and through writing. His tests are really not that hard though, if you study everything and get the basic concepts down fine you will do good. He really tries his best. Youtube will be your friend. But I made an A in the class, so its possible.
Avoid Avoid by all means nessesary

Hershkovits is a great, great guy. Unfortunately, he cannot teach to save his life. He writes his lecture notes on a projector, and his handwriting is non-discernible. He never actually teaches you how to use the formulas in his lectures. He never uses numbers, just Greek letters that he assumes we all know. But in the end, he IS a good guy.

If you go to his lectures then you are waisting your time. He rights on a projector and his hand writing is unreadable. He spends the entire class proving how formulas are derived instead of focusing on how to apply the actual formula. He gives out reviews before the test but they have nothing to do with the test. A nice guy but not a good teacher.

AVOID!!! Especially for lab. He will take off at least ten points on every question wrong in lab even though each question is actually work 3-4 points. Test was four questions and not extremely hard but when you have no idea what's going on in class, then yes, it's hard. HIs lecture notes are right out of the book.  No extra credit or help.
probably the worst professor i've ever had.

He's smart, but doesn't explain material very well & can be super confusing. Be prepared to teach yourself and get a tutor. Sometimes he assumes that you already know terms or techniques and frequently references skills learned in higher level classes such as Calc 3 (the class is Physics 1). He also has horrendous handwriting and a French accent.
